dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Motivating your team is just one part of the job—your real first job is helping other people succeed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Motivating your team is just one part of the job-your real first job is helping other people succeed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Your first job is to help other people. Your second is your actual job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that ties into the idea of coaching, not directing. A great leader is a teacher, not a dictator.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that ties into the idea of coaching, not directing. A great leader is a teacher, not a dictator.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A great leader is a teacher and a coach, not a dictator.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they have to find that balance between giving up too much control and being too controlling, which isn't a fixed ratio.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they have to find that balance between giving up too much control and being too controlling, which isn't a fixed ratio.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its about finding the balance between giving up too much control and being too controlling. A great leader knows that there is no specific ratio to this, and that it changes depending on the situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it changes depending on the situation. And you've got to tailor your approach to each team member's work preferences.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it changes depending on the situation. And you've got to tailor your approach to each team member's work preferences.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Learn how your team members work best, and tailor your coaching to match their work style.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which can be tough with very large teams—you might need to experiment with different styles to see what gets results.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which can be tough with very large teams-you might need to experiment with different styles to see what gets results.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When youre responsible for very large teams, its much more difficult to know which style will work best, so its best to experiment with a few styles until you find the one that gets the desired results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's being adept. Leaders have to be ready for sudden changes, like a deadline moving up overnight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's being adept. Leaders have to be ready for sudden changes, like a deadline moving up overnight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders are prepared for change to happen at any time. The next day, the deadline could get moved up, and the leader would have to assign tasks and provide more structure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they need to rally the team quickly, um, whether that means giving free rein or assigning tasks more directly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they need to rally the team quickly, um, whether that means giving free rein or assigning tasks more directly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One day that could mean giving the team free reign to come up with ideas for a project and a deadline that they need to meet. The next day, the deadline could get moved up, and the leader would have to assign tasks and provide more structure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's about paying equal attention to both the process and the people. If you ignore one, the other suffers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's about paying equal attention to both the process and the people. If you ignore one, the other suffers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paying equal attention to both is important. If you ignore one, the other will suffer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And respect is huge too. Micromanaging is a quick way to lose it—employees need trust and space to take risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And respect is huge too. Micromanaging is a quick way to lose it-employees need trust and space to take risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No employee likes to be micromanaged, as it indicates to them that you don't trust their abilities. In fact, its one of the quickest ways to lose respect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. When employees feel comfortable coming to you with questions, that's a sign of a respected leader.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. When employees feel comfortable coming to you with questions, that's a sign of a respected leader.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A sure sign of a respected and trusted leader is when employees are comfortable coming to them with questions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And sometimes that means rolling up your sleeves and working alongside them, not just delegating from afar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And sometimes that means rolling up your sleeves and working alongside them, not just delegating from afar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The best leaders have no problem working alongside their employees and arent afraid to roll up their sleeves and jump in to help the team when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Communication is another key—great leaders are master communicators who can switch between listening, advising, directing…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Communication is another key-great leaders are master communicators who can switch between listening, advising, directing...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders can tailor their communication style to meet the needs of any situation. There are six key communication styles you should be familiar with - listening, advising, directing, motivating, teaching, and coaching.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like using those six styles: listening, advising, directing, motivating, teaching, and coaching.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like using those six styles: listening, advising, directing, motivating, teaching, and coaching.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are six key communication styles you should be familiar with - listening, advising, directing, motivating, teaching, and coaching.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It all comes down to practice. No matter your title, you can develop these skills and become a great leader.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It all comes down to practice. No matter your title, you can develop these skills and become a great leader.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Practice these skills, and you'll be on the path to great leadership. Ashira Prossack, Women@Forbes

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Ashira Prosper really nailed it in that Forbes piece—leadership is next-level management with strong people skills.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ashira Prosper really nailed it in that Forbes piece-leadership is next-level management with strong people skills.
